questions.question_text:
A network administrator needs to access a remote site and log into the site switch using secure methods. The administrator first has to gain access to the server
GUI. Which of the following access control methods will be used?

discussion.content: I had to read this question a few times to really understand what I think they are asking. (Wording of these questions is terrible). anyway, when you first read the question, you may think aha, GUI= No SSH. Second, you may think SECURE=No Telnet. Then you are left with A and B. B satisfies the security requirement but not the GUI requirement. That only leaves you with A. The key phrase here is "administrator first has to gain access to the server GUI"
SSH is run over the command line, it has no GUI therefore cannot be the answer. RDP is the only one there that has a GUI although it may not be secure.
Also thought SSH but the requirement to access server using GUI swayed it to RDP.

The administrator "first" has to gain access to the server
GUI

comments.content: It has a GUI though so wins by defualt lol

discussion.content: RDP is not secure

comments.content: Arent there linux GUI for SSH? I guess i need to assume windows first unless it states linux?

discussion.content: okay nevermind i figured it out...they asked for a secure method of accessing the gui therefore it would be RDP since SSH has no GUI

comments.content: i was wondering the same thing could anyone clarify?

discussion.content: shouldn't the answer be SSH?
Being a boot up issue, the problem lies with the Operating system, not the configuration

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/internetworking/troubleshooting/guide/tr1903.html#wp1021948
Router Cannot Network Boot from Another Router part
on the site from my logic it states that the new device isnt configured properly for the image of old switch.
so operating system it is.
The reason it is not C is because it states the configuration files are the same.
I think it should be C, ant advice?

comments.content: If the switch doesn't boot up, it's likely due to the operating system, not the configuration of the switch itself. Even with a vlan mismatch, the switch should completely boot up.

Even if there is a VLAN mismatch device should be able to completely boot up. And you can even think of it like this, "If a device doesn't completely boot up, how are you going to configure the settings of that device?"

questions.question_text: A technician attempts to replace a switch with a new one of similar model from the same vendor. When the technician moves the fiber and SFP plug, the switch does not completely boot up. Considering that the config files are the same, which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the failure?

Users have been experiencing slow network response times, and management has asked the network technician to provide evidence of network improvement.
After optimizing the network, which of the following would be required?

discussion.content: and that is my opinion .
most of the time when user have this kind of problems , 1st question will be what is the performance of the baseline?
that what i got from the web .

C is the correct answer because network baselining is the act of measuring and rating the performance of a network in real-time situations. Providing a network baseline requires testing and reporting of the physical connectivity, normal network utilization, protocol usage, peak network utilization, and average throughput of the network usage

questions.question_text: A NGFW is continuously sending alerts regarding traffic from an internal database server. An old DHCP service, which was used before a dedicated server was installed, is still running on the server. Which of the following practices could have prevented this incident?

choices.A: Preventing UDP on the host firewall

discussion.content: The key word here is OLD

questions.question_text: An ISP technician frequently needs to administer a router remotely in the event of a configuration error or WAN outage. Which of the following technologies would facilitate the required connectivity?

discussion.content: I think this should be Out-of-band, SSH doesn't work when error happened on WAN.

Selected Answer: C
It should be Out of Band
connecting remotely to the router, can u do that with oob

Selected Answer: C
As most of the comment I saw, I also think the correct answer is C Out Of Band, because SSH will not work when the WAN is down/not available

comments.content: Out-of-band (OOB) management is a method of remotely controlling and managing critical IT assets and network equipment using a secure connection through a secondary interface that is physically separate from the primary network connection. This enables administrators to gain control even during infrastructure faults.

discussion.content: The correct answer is C. Out-of-band.

When a dedicated channel is established for managing network devices, it is
known as out-of-band management. A connection can be established via a
console router, or modem, and this can be used to ensure management
connectivity independent of the status of in-band network connectivity (which
would include serial port connections, VNC, and SSH). Out-of-band
management lets the administrator monitor, access, and manage network
infrastructure devices remotely and securely, even when everything else is down
I suppose SSH works over dial-up. Right?
No SSH when WAN isn’t available just to clarify things, so out-of-band is the correct answer

The answer IS SSH because the ISP technician is remotely configuring the device and needs secure connection to the device, the connection would already be an OOB connection, but SSH specifies that connection will be a secure one.

comments.content:
OOB can be remote.
https://www.digi.com/solutions/by-technology/out-of-band-management

And the question doesn't specify a secure connection, just something that will facilitate a connection.
Edit: OOB is when you physically connect a cable to the router to configure it, the ISP technician is remotely accessing the router.

discussion.content:
I see no reason why OOB would be wrong or any situation where SSH would be 100% correct.
I am going with OOB

I believe the answer should be C Out of Band,
however, since it is a remote connection, CompTIA wants secure remote connection therefore SSH into the router to manage it
I also think that out-of-band its the correct answer.

I also think that correct answer is C.
More info: 
https://www.techopedia.com/definition/21211/out-of-band-management
